clinical_study.brief_title: The Prediction Model of Hypoxemia for Safe Bronchoscopy
clinical_study.official_title: The Prediction Model of Hypoxemia for Safe Bronchoscopy Under MAC Anesthesia

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to develop the hypoxemia prediction model during fiberoptic bronchoscopy under MAC(monitored anesthesia care) anesthesia.

detailed_description.textblock: Currently, diverse sedatives and analgesic methods are used during fiberoptic bronchoscopy for reducing patients' discomfort and facilities of procedures as British Thoracic Society recommendation. MAC anesthesia, one of the widely used sedative method during bronchoscopy, have many advantages, occurrence of respiratory depression, hypoxemia are not uncommon during the procedures. The investigators try to find out risk factors and develop the prediction model for hypoxemia during bronchoscopy under MAC anesthesia.

primary_outcome.measure: Lowest oxygen saturation during bronchoscopy, development of hypoxemia(SpO2<90%) during bronchoscopy
primary_outcome.time_frame: during the fiberoptic bronchoscopy, estimated procedure time is about 15min

secondary_outcome.measure: time delay for procedure due to hypoxemia
secondary_outcome.time_frame: during the fiberoptic bronchoscopy, estimated procedure time is about 15min

secondary_outcome.measure: the proportion of subjects with snoring
secondary_outcome.time_frame: during the fiberoptic bronchoscopy, estimated procedure time is about 15min

study_pop.textblock: Patienst who are planned to get fiberoptic bronchoscopy under MAC anesthesia in Seoul National University Bundang Hospital

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age> 15 yrs
- patients who are planned to get fiberoptic bronchoscopy under MAC anesthesia in Seoul National University Bundang Hospital
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who will get Endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial needle aspiration
- patients whose baseline oxygen saturation is below 90%
- Intubated patients
- Patients do not agree with the study enrollment
